unnormalised: Delhi's air quality continues to be a hot topic, and not in a good way, folks! Remember that smoggy Diwali? Well, things haven't exactly cleared up entirely.
normalised: Delhi's air quality continues to be a hot topic, and not in a good way, folks! Remember that smoggy Diwali? Well, things haven't exactly cleared up entirely.

unnormalised: The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) reports that while there have been marginal improvements compared to last year, we still have a long way to go before breathing easy. Think of it like that dramatic scene in "Swades" - imagine Mohan Bhargava wanting clean air for Charanpur!
normalised: The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) reports that while there have been marginal improvements compared to last year, we still have a long way to go before breathing easy. Think of it like that dramatic scene in "Swades" - imagine Mohan Bhargava wanting clean air for Charanpur!

unnormalised: Particulate matter levels, especially PM2.5, are still exceeding permissible limits in many areas, including Anand Vihar and RK Puram. It's like a persistent cough that just won't quit.
normalised: Particulate matter levels, especially P M two point five, are still exceeding permissible limits in many areas, including Anand Vihar and R K Puram. It's like a persistent cough that just won't quit.

unnormalised: Experts from IIT Kanpur are working on new technologies to combat air pollution, but real change needs a collective effort. From carpooling to planting more trees (think of it as your personal Van Mahotsav!), every little bit helps. Let's all pitch in to make Delhi's air breathable again! Rs. 1000 fine for burning garbage is a small price to pay for cleaner air, right? Hopefully, we will be breathing freely within 5 years, reducing PM2.5 by 50% across 100 km radius.
normalised: Experts from I I T Kanpur are working on new technologies to combat air pollution, but real change needs a collective effort. From carpooling to planting more trees (think of it as your personal Van Mahotsav!), every little bit helps. Let's all pitch in to make Delhi's air breathable again! Rupee one thousand fine for burning garbage is a small price to pay for cleaner air, right? Hopefully, we will be breathing freely within five years, reducing P M two point five by fifty percent across one hundred kilometer radius.
